bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Jonathan Mathews and John Goodwin, 1701 June 2

div1.p: Robert Carter writes the London merchants Jonathan Mathews and John Goodwin that he is one of the exectors of Ralph Wormeley and a guardian of Wormeley's sons; he is sending 27 hogsheads of tobaccoe belonging to the estate for sale. They shall have the majority of the business of the estate if he can arrange it. Carter reports the arrival of goods sent to Wormeley, and encloses an order for more to be charged to the estate.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Jonathan Mathews and John Goodwin, June 2, 1701

opener.dateline:
[Rappahannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]
June the 2d. 1701
Jonathan Mathews &
John Goodwin—

div1.p:
Mr. Secretary Wormeley in his Will (a Coppy whereof is herein sent you)
hath Appointed me one of his Executrs. in the Minor Age of his Sons. In
Respect to Our Long Acquaintance, my Relation to his Widdow & Children
and the great Desire I ever had, and hope alwayes shall preserve, to
befriend the fatherless, and not any Interest of my Own, Expecting nothing
but my Labour for my hire, and perhapps to be Censur'd for a Wrong
doer att Last I have Intermeddle with that Estate & have Shipt the To=
-baccoe belonging thereto, 27 hogsheads whereof are on board [John] Burford & Consign'd
to you, they are of his own Cropps wch. you Comended very much last Year
I hope these may prove as good. I must tell you, 'tis the largest parcell Comes
to any One Merchant from that Concern, not at all to the liking of the
Rest, of the Exrs. tho' so long as you are kind in your Care of that Concern
I shall Endeavour to continue to you a Considerable part of the Consign=
-ments. your Goods to Esqr. Wormeley per Burford Came safe to hand, Except
the White sugr. wch. Cannot be heard of, Burford sayes, it never Came Aboard
pray Enquire into it, and sett the thing to Rights. In the Ballance of your
Last Accot. Currtt. you Debitt your self to that Estate £76:-:8 besides 21 hogsheads
unaccounted for, 15 of wch. your Lettrs. sayes, are sold, 6 Remaines unsold
of them you hope to make Eleven pence per pound or more soe far in
answer to your Lettrs.

In Regard you are like to have the most money, I have here En=
-closed sent an Invoice for goods for the provision of Esqr. Wormeleys
family, and Desire you to send them in, in some good Shipp bound
for this River Upon the proper Accot. & risque of that Estate Marking them
wth. the Tobaccoe Mark, & Consigning them to me as One of the Exrs. as
Aforesaid, And so I Desire you'll lett your Accot. Run. have, Not Else upon
this Subject at present but Res[pec]t[s]

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Christ Church Parish, Lancaster County, Processioners' Returns, 1711-1783,and Wormeley Estate Papers, 1701-1710, 1716, Acc. 30126, Archives Research Services, Library of Virginia, Richmond, 142.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.

[1] John Burford commanded the Elizabeth and Mary, a London ship of 20 men and 10 guns, built at Ipswich in 1697, and of 250 tons. She was owned by Goodwin and Mathews, Samuel Landford, Nicholas Goodwin, William Holditch, and Job Mathews. This ship sank during a voyage to Virginia in the winter of 1701-1702; John Burford later commanded the Mansfield by which Carter sent tobacco to London. (1700 Convoy List; Naval officer's return for Rappahannock River, CO5/1441, ff. 13)
